title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Marcus is having a water balloon party. He has 100 balloons. Each balloon holds 3 ounces of water. He can buy 50 ounces of water for $2.5 a bottle. If he walks into the store with 2 $10 bills, how much change will he have after he buys all the water he needs?

Marcus needs 300 ounces of water because 100 x 3 = <<100*3=300>>300
He needs 6 bottles because 300 / 50 = <<300/50=6>>6
This will cost $15 because 6 x 2.5 = <<6*2.5=15>>15
He has $20 because 2 x 10 = <<2*10=20>>20
He will have $5 change because 20 - 15 = <<20-15=5>>5. Answer: \boxed{5}.


Question: Marcus is having a water balloon party. He has 100 balloons. Each balloon holds 3 ounces of water. He can buy 50 ounces of water for $2.5 a bottle. If he walks into the store with 2 $10 bills, how much change will he have after he buys all the water he needs?

He needs 300 ounces of water because 100 x 3 = <<100*3=300>>300
He needs 6 bottles of water because 300 / 50 = <<300/50=6>>6
He spends 15 dollars because 6 x 2.5 = <<6*2.5=15>>15
He will have 5 dollars left because 20 - 15 = <<20-15=5>>5. Answer: \boxed{5}.


Question: Marcus is having a water balloon party. He has 100 balloons. Each balloon holds 3 ounces of water. He can buy 50 ounces of water for $2.5 a bottle. If he walks into the store with 2 $10 bills, how much change will he have after he buys all the water he needs?

He needs 300 ounces of water because 100 x 3 = <<100*3=300>>300
He needs to buy 6 bottles because 300 / 50 = <<300/50=6>>6
This will cost $15 because 6 x 2.5 = <<6*2.5=15>>15
He will have $5 left because 20 - 15 = <<20-15=5>>5. Answer: \boxed{5}.


Question: Marcus is having a water balloon party. He has 100 balloons. Each balloon holds 3 ounces of water. He can buy 50 ounces of water for $2.5 a bottle. If he walks into the store with 2 $10 bills, how much change will he have after he buys all the water he needs?

Marcus will need a total of 100 * 3 = <<100*3=300>>300 ounces of water.
He will need to buy 300 / 50 = <<300/50=6>>6 bottles of water.
The water will cost him 6 * 2.5 = $<<6*2.5=15>>15.
He will have to hand over 2 * 10 = 20 dollars.
Thus, Marcus will get 20 - 15 = $<<20-15=5>>5 in change. Answer: \boxed{5}.


Question: Jake is from a conservative household so during lunch at school one day, he gave one-quarter of his feeding allowance to a hungry friend. If candies cost 20 cents apiece and Jake's feeding allowance is $4, how many candies can his friend purchase with the money Jake gave to him?

Jake gave one-quarter of his feeding allowance, which is $4 * (1/4) = $<<4*(1/4)=1>>1.
Jake's friend can purchase $1 / $0.20/candy = <<1/0.2=5>>5 candies. Answer: \boxed{5}.


Question: Toby is filling his swimming pool for the summer. The pool normally takes 50 hours to fill. He knows his hose runs at 100 gallons per hour. Water costs 1 cent for 10 gallons. How many dollars does it cost to fill the pool?
text:
Toby needs to fill the pool with 100 gallons per hour for 50 hours, so he needs a total of 100 * 50 = 5000 gallons.
He will need to pay for 5000 / 10 = 500 units of water.
Each unit of water costs 1 cent, so it will cost him 500 * $0.01 = $5. Answer: \boxed{5}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Gary has 6 pounds of flour. He will use 4 pounds of flour to make cakes which require 0.5 pounds of flour each. The remaining 2 pounds of flour will be used to bake cupcakes, which require 1/5 pounds of flour. He plans to sell the cakes for $2.5 each and the cupcakes for $1 each in the school's bake sale. How much will Gary earn?

Gary can make 4/0.5 = <<4/0.5=8>>8 cakes.
He will earn 8 x $2.5 = $<<8*2.5=20>>20 for the cakes.
He can make 2/ 1/5 = 10 cupcakes.
He will earn 10 x $1 = $<<10*1=10>>10 for the cupcakes.
Therefore Gary will earn $20 + $10 = $<<20+10=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Gary has 6 pounds of flour. He will use 4 pounds of flour to make cakes which require 0.5 pounds of flour each. The remaining 2 pounds of flour will be used to bake cupcakes, which require 1/5 pounds of flour. He plans to sell the cakes for $2.5 each and the cupcakes for $1 each in the school's bake sale. How much will Gary earn?

Gary can bake 4/0.5 = <<4/0.5=8>>8 cakes.
He can bake 2/1/5 = 2/(1/5) = <<2/(1/5)=10>>10 cupcakes.
He will earn $2.5 x 8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20 from the cakes.
He will earn $1 x 10 = $<<1*10=10>>10 from the cupcakes.
Therefore, Gary will earn $20 + $10 = $<<20+10=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Gary has 6 pounds of flour. He will use 4 pounds of flour to make cakes which require 0.5 pounds of flour each. The remaining 2 pounds of flour will be used to bake cupcakes, which require 1/5 pounds of flour. He plans to sell the cakes for $2.5 each and the cupcakes for $1 each in the school's bake sale. How much will Gary earn?

Gary can make 4/0.5 = <<4/0.5=8>>8 cakes.
So, he will earn $2.5 x 8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20 for cakes.
And he can bake 2/1/5 = <<2/1/5=10>>10 cupcakes.
So, he will earn $1 x 10 = $<<1*10=10>>10 for cupcakes.
Therefore, Gary will earn a total of $20 + $10 = $<<20+10=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: Gary has 6 pounds of flour. He will use 4 pounds of flour to make cakes which require 0.5 pounds of flour each. The remaining 2 pounds of flour will be used to bake cupcakes, which require 1/5 pounds of flour. He plans to sell the cakes for $2.5 each and the cupcakes for $1 each in the school's bake sale. How much will Gary earn?

Gary can make 4/0.5 = <<4/0.5=8>>8 cakes.
He can make 2/0.2 = <<2/0.2=10>>10 cupcakes.
Gary will earn 8 x $2.5 = $<<8*2.5=20>>20 for selling the cakes.
He will earn 10 x $1 = $<<10*1=10>>10 for selling the cupcakes.
Therefore, Gary will earn $20 + $10 = $<<20+10=30>>30. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: A kiddy gift shop sells bracelets at $4 each, keychains at $5 each, and coloring books at $3 each. Paula and Olive want to buy presents for their friends. Paula buys two bracelets and a keychain, while Olive buys a coloring book and a bracelet.  How much do Paula and Olive spend in total?

Two bracelets cost 2 x $4 = $<<2*4=8>>8.
So Paula spends $8 + $5 = $<<8+5=13>>13.
While Olive spends $3 + $4 = $<<3+4=7>>7.
Therefore, Paula and Olive spend $13 + $7 = $<<13+7=20>>20 in total. Answer: \boxed{20}.


Question: Andy bakes and sells birthday cakes. To make two cakes he spends $12 on ingredients, and $1 on packaging for each cake. Andy sells each cake for $15. How much money does Andy make for each cake?
text:
Andy spends $12 on ingredients for 2 cakes, so he spends $12/2 = $6 on ingredients for each cake.
Andy spends $1 on packaging for each cake.
Therefore, Andy spends a total of $6 + $1 = $7 for each cake.
Andy sells each cake for $15.
Therefore, Andy makes a profit of $15 - $7 = $8 for each cake. Answer: \boxed{8}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Yun had 20 paperclips initially, but then lost 12. Marion has 1/4 more than what Yun currently has, plus 7. How many paperclips does Marion have?

Yun has 20 - 12 = <<20-12=8>>8 paperclips.
Then, Marion has (1/4) x 8 + 7 = <<(1/4)*8+7=9>>9 paperclips. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: In the beginning, Justine had 10 more rubber bands than Bailey but 2 fewer bands than Ylona. Bailey decided to give two bands each to Justine and Ylona so that he is left with only 8 rubber bands. How many rubber bands did Ylona have in the beginning?

Let x be the number of rubber bands Ylona had in the beginning.
Justine had x-2 bands.
Bailey had (x-2)-10=x-12 bands.
After Bailey gave two bands each to Justine and Ylona, he was left with x-12-2-2=x-16 bands.
Since Bailey was left with 8 bands, then x-16=8.
Thus, Ylona had x=8+16=<<8+16=24>>24 bands in the beginning. Answer: \boxed{24}.


Question: In the beginning, Justine had 10 more rubber bands than Bailey but 2 fewer bands than Ylona. Bailey decided to give two bands each to Justine and Ylona so that he is left with only 8 rubber bands. How many rubber bands did Ylona have in the beginning?

Justine initially had 10 more rubber bands than Bailey, so let's assume Bailey had x rubber bands.
So, Justine had x + 10 rubber bands.
Justine had 2 fewer rubber bands than Ylona, so Ylona had x + 10 + 2 = x + 12 rubber bands.
Bailey gave two bands each to Justine and Ylona so he had x - 2 - 2 = x - 4 rubber bands.
Since Bailey is left with 8 rubber bands, we have x - 4 = 8.
Adding 4 to both sides, we get x = 8 + 4 = <<8+4=12>>12.
So Ylona initially had x + 12 = 12 + 12 = <<12+12=24>>24 rubber bands. Answer: \boxed{24}.


Question: Hash has nine more than half as many toys as Bill has. If Bill has 60 toys, how many total toys do the boys have?

Half of 60 is 60 / 2 = <<60/2=30>>30.
So, Hash has 30 + 9 = <<30+9=39>>39 toys.
Therefore, the two boys have a total of 60 + 39 = <<60+39=99>>99 toys. Answer: \boxed{99}.


Question: In the beginning, Justine had 10 more rubber bands than Bailey but 2 fewer bands than Ylona. Bailey decided to give two bands each to Justine and Ylona so that he is left with only 8 rubber bands. How many rubber bands did Ylona have in the beginning?

If Bailey has 8 rubber bands after giving 2 each to Justine and Ylona, Bailey initially had 8+2+2 =<<8+2+2=12>>12 bands before giving the two bands.
Justine had 10 bands more than Bailey at the beginning which means she had 12+10 = <<10+12=22>>22 bands.
There were 2 fewer rubber bands than Ylona at the start than Justine had, meaning Ylona had 22+2 = <<22+2=24>>24 bands in the beginning. Answer: \boxed{24}.


Question: A new edition Geometry book has 450 pages which are 230 pages less than twice as many pages as the old edition. How many pages did the old edition Geometry book have?
text:
Let x be the number of pages in the old edition Geometry book.
The new edition has twice as many pages as the old edition, so it has 2x pages.
The new edition has 230 pages less than twice as many pages as the old edition, so 2x - 230 = 450.
Adding 230 to both sides, we get 2x = 450 + 230 = 680.
Dividing both sides by 2, we get x = 680 / 2 = <<680/2=340>>340.
Therefore, the old edition Geometry book had 340 pages. Answer: \boxed{340}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jill is painting her 20 toenails and fingernails. She paints 6 of her nails purple, 8 of them blue, and the rest striped. What is the difference in percentage points between the percentage of nails painted blue and the percentage painted striped?

The total number of striped nails is 20 - 6 - 8 = <<20-6-8=6>>6.
The percentage of striped nails is 6/20 * 100% = 30%.
The difference between the percentage of blue nails and striped nails is 8/20 * 100% - 30% = 40% - 30% = <<8/20*100%-30%=10>>10%. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: Jill is painting her 20 toenails and fingernails. She paints 6 of her nails purple, 8 of them blue, and the rest striped. What is the difference in percentage points between the percentage of nails painted blue and the percentage painted striped?

The total number of blue and striped nails is 6 + 8 = <<6+8=14>>14 nails.
Jill paints 20 - 14 = <<20-14=6>>6 striped nails.
The percentage of blue nails is 8 / 20 * 100% = 40%.
The percentage of striped nails is 6 / 20 * 100% = 30%.
The difference between the two percentages is 40% - 30% = 10%. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: Jill is painting her 20 toenails and fingernails. She paints 6 of her nails purple, 8 of them blue, and the rest striped. What is the difference in percentage points between the percentage of nails painted blue and the percentage painted striped?

There are a total of 20 nails. If we subtract the number of purple nails and blue nails, we find that 20-6-8=<<20-6-8=6>>6 nails are striped.
The percentage of nails that are blue is 8/20=0.4*100%=<<8/20=40>>40%.
The percentage of nails that are striped is 6/20=0.3*100%=<<6/20=30>>30%.
The difference in percentage points between the percentage of nails painted blue and striped is 40-30=<<40-30=10>>10%. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: Tim's car goes down in value by $1000 a year.  He bought it for $20,000. How much is it worth after 6 years?

It goes down in value by 1000*6=$<<1000*6=6000>>6000
So it is worth 20000-6000=$<<20000-6000=14000>>14000. Answer: \boxed{14000}.


Question: Lyra bought a pair of shoes at a 20% discount.  If she paid $480, how much was the original price of the pair of shoes?

Let X be the original price of the shoes.
The shoes were on sale for X - X*.20 = $480
So the original price of the shoe was X = $480/.8 = $<<600=600>>600. Answer: \boxed{600}.


Question: Jack buys a squat rack for $2500.  The barbell cost 1/10 as much.  How much did he pay for everything?
text:
The cost of the barbell is 1/10 * $2500 = $250.
Therefore, Jack paid a total of $2500 + $250 = $<<2500+250=2750>>2750 for everything. Answer: \boxed{2750}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jack goes up three flights of stairs, then down six flights of stairs. If each flight of stairs has 12 steps that each each 8 inches high, how many feet further down is Jack than when he started?

Jack has gone up 3*12=<<3*12=36>>36*8=<<3*12*8=288>>288 inches.
Jack has gone down 6*12=<<6*12=72>>72*8=<<6*12*8=576>>576 inches.
Jack has gone 576-288=<<576-288=288>>288 inches further down.
Jack has gone 288/12=<<288/12=24>>24 feet further down. Answer: \boxed{24}.


Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby has 5 balls * 80 rotations per ball = <<5*80=400>>400 rotations.
Toby's friend has 4 apples * 101 rotations per apple = <<4*101=404>>404 rotations.
The winner has 404 >=  400 meaning the maximum is 404 rotations. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

The boy gives 12/3 = <<12/3=4>>4 oranges to his brother.
The remainder is 12 - 4 = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges.
The boy gives his friend 8/4 = <<8/4=2>>2 oranges. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: In a 60-item exam, Liza got 90% of the items correctly. Her best friend, Rose, got 2 more correct answers than her. How many incorrect answers did Rose have?

The number of correct items Liza got in the exam is 60 x 90/100 = <<60*90/100=54>>54.
Rose got 54 + 2 = <<54+2=56>>56 correct answers.
Thus, Rose had 60 - 56 = <<60-56=4>>4 incorrect answers. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Jack goes up three flights of stairs, then down six flights of stairs. If each flight of stairs has 12 steps that each each 8 inches high, how many feet further down is Jack than when he started?

Jack goes up 3 flights of stairs, or 3*12*8=<<3*12*8=288>>288 inches.
Then Jack goes down 6 flights of stairs, or 6*12*8=<<6*12*8=576>>576 inches.
Therefore, Jack ends up 576-288=<<576-288=288>>288 inches further down.
Since there are 12 inches in a foot, Jack is 288/12=<<288/12=24>>24 feet further down. Answer: \boxed{24}.


Question: A bus has a carrying capacity of 80 people. At the first pickup point, the number of people who entered the bus was 3/5 of its carrying capacity. If there were 50 people at the next pick-up point, how many people could not take the bus because it was full?
text:
At the first pick-up point, 3/5 * 80 = <<3/5*80=48>>48 people entered the bus.
Therefore, there were 80 - 48 = <<80-48=32>>32 available spaces left on the bus.
At the next pick-up point, 50 people wanted to take the bus.
Since there were only 32 available spaces left, 50 - 32 = <<50-32=18>>18 people could not take the bus because it was full. Answer: \boxed{18}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: The math questions in a contest are divided into three rounds: easy, average, and hard. There are corresponding points given for each round. That is 2, 3, and 5 points for every correct answer in the easy, average, and hard rounds, respectively. Suppose Kim got 6 correct answers in the easy; 2 correct answers in the average; and 4 correct answers in the difficult round, what are her total points in the contest?

Kim's points in the easy round is 6 x 2 = <<6*2=12>>12.
Her points in the average round is 2 x 3 = <<2*3=6>>6.
Her points in the hard round is 4 x 5 = <<4*5=20>>20.
Therefore, her total points is 12 + 6 + 20 = <<12+6+20=38>>38. Answer: \boxed{38}.


Question: David and Brenda are playing Scrabble. Brenda is ahead by 22 points when she makes a 15-point play. David responds with a 32-point play. By how many points is Brenda now ahead?

After her 15-point play, Brenda is ahead by 22 + 15 = <<22+15=37>>37 points.
After his 32-point play, David is only behind by 37 - 32 = <<37-32=5>>5 points. Answer: \boxed{5}.


Question: The ages of three brothers are consecutive integers with the sum of 96.  How old is the youngest brother?

Let's assume the three brothers ages are $n-1,$ $n,$ and $n+1$ for some integer $n.$ Since their sum is 96, we have  \begin{align*}
(n-1) + n + (n+1) &= 3n \\
&= 96.
\end{align*}Dividing both sides of this equation by 3 gives $n = 32.$ Thus, the youngest brother is $n - 1 = \boxed{31}$ years old.


Question: The math questions in a contest are divided into three rounds: easy, average, and hard. There are corresponding points given for each round. That is 2, 3, and 5 points for every correct answer in the easy, average, and hard rounds, respectively. Suppose Kim got 6 correct answers in the easy; 2 correct answers in the average; and 4 correct answers in the difficult round, what are her total points in the contest?

Kim's total points in the easy round are 6 x 2 = <<6*2=12>>12 points.
Her total points in the average round are 2 x 3 = <<2*3=6>>6 points.
Her total points in the hard round are 4 x 5 = <<4*5=20>>20 points.
Therefore, Kim's total points in the contest are 12 + 6 + 20 = <<12+6+20=38>>38 points. Answer: \boxed{38}.


Question: Adam has 50 balls. 20 balls are red, 10 are blue, and the rest are either pink or orange. If there are 3 times as many pink as orange balls, how many orange balls are there?

There are 20+10=<<20+10=30>>30 red and blue balls.
Thus, there are 50-30=<<50-30=20>>20 pink and orange balls.
Let x be the number of orange balls.
There are 3*x=3x pink balls.
Thus, there are x+3x=<<4=4>>4x=20 balls.
Thus, the number of orange balls x=20/4=<<20/4=5>>5. Answer: \boxed{5}.


Question: If the sum of two numbers is 33, and if the second number is twice the first number, what is the second number?
text: Let x be the first number. Since the second number is twice the first number, the second number is 2x. The sum of the two numbers is x + 2x = 3x. We are given that the sum of the two numbers is 33, so we have 3x = 33. Dividing both sides of this equation by 3 gives x = 11. The second number is 2x = 2(11) = 22. Answer: \boxed{22}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jillian had 80 oranges which she had bought to give to her friends. She divided each orange into ten equal pieces for each friend to get four pieces. How many friends were there?

Jillian has a total of 80 * 10 = <<80*10=800>>800 equal pieces of oranges.
Thus she had 800 / 4 = <<800/4=200>>200 friends. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Jillian had 80 oranges which she had bought to give to her friends. She divided each orange into ten equal pieces for each friend to get four pieces. How many friends were there?

Jillian had a total of 80 x 10 = <<80*10=800>>800 pieces.
Therefore there were 800 / 4 = <<800/4=200>>200 friends. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Jillian had 80 oranges which she had bought to give to her friends. She divided each orange into ten equal pieces for each friend to get four pieces. How many friends were there?

Jillian had a total of 80 oranges * 10 pieces = <<80*10=800>>800 pieces.
Therefore, there were 800 pieces / 4 pieces per friend = <<800/4=200>>200 four-piece servings which means there were 200 friends. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Jillian, Savannah, and Clayton were collecting shells on the beach. Jillian collected 29, Savannah collected 17, and Clayton collected 8. They decided that they wanted to give the shells to two of their friends who had just arrived. They put their shells together and distributed them evenly to each friend. How many shells did each friend get?

Jillian, Savannah, and Clayton collected a total of 29 + 17 + 8 = <<29+17+8=54>>54 shells.
When distributed evenly, each friend received 54/2 = <<54/2=27>>27 shells. Answer: \boxed{27}.


Question: Jillian had 80 oranges which she had bought to give to her friends. She divided each orange into ten equal pieces for each friend to get four pieces. How many friends were there?

Jillian divided 80 oranges into 10 equal pieces.
The total number of pieces obtained from the oranges is 80 x 10 = <<80*10=800>>800 pieces.
Jillian had 4 pieces for each friend.
Therefore, she had 800/4 = <<800/4=200>>200 friends. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: A school has 100 students. Half of the students are girls, the other half are boys.  20% of the girls have dogs at home and 10% of the boys have dogs at home.  How many students own dogs?
text:
There are a total of 100 / 2 = 50 girls and boys each.
Out of the 50 girls, 20% have dogs, which is 50 x 0.2 = 10 girls.
Out of the 50 boys, 10% have dogs, which is 50 x 0.1 = 5 boys.
Therefore, there are a total of 10 + 5 = <<10+5=15>>15 students who own dogs. Answer: \boxed{15}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Carter has a jar with 20 green M&Ms and 20 red M&Ms. He eats 12 of the green M&Ms, then his sister comes and eats half the red M&Ms and adds 14 yellow M&Ms. If Carter picks an M&M at random now, what is the percentage chance he'll get a green M&M?

Before Carter's sister eats the red M&Ms and adds the yellow M&Ms, there are 20 + 20 = <<20+20=40>>40 M&Ms in total.
After Carter eats 12 green M&Ms, there are 20 - 12 = <<20-12=8>>8 green M&Ms remaining.
After Carter's sister eats half the red M&Ms, there are 20 / 2 = <<20/2=10>>10 red M&Ms remaining.
After Carter's sister adds the yellow M&Ms, there are 10 + 14 = <<10+14=24>>24 non-green M&Ms remaining.
Therefore, there are 8 green M&Ms / (8 + 24 non-green M&Ms) = 8 / 32 = 1 / 4 = <<8/(8+24)=1/4>>1/4 = <<1/4=0.25>>0.25 = 25% chance of getting a green M&M. Answer: \boxed{25}.


Question: Carter has a jar with 20 green M&Ms and 20 red M&Ms. He eats 12 of the green M&Ms, then his sister comes and eats half the red M&Ms and adds 14 yellow M&Ms. If Carter picks an M&M at random now, what is the percentage chance he'll get a green M&M?

After eating 12 green M&Ms, Carter has 20 - 12 = <<20-12=8>>8 remaining green M&Ms.
After his sister eats half the red M&Ms, there are 20/2 = <<20/2=10>>10 remaining red M&Ms.
After adding the yellow M&Ms, there are 10 + 14 = <<10+14=24>>24 total yellow and red M&Ms.
There are a total 8 + 24 = <<8+24=32>>32 green and yellow M&Ms.
Thus, Carter has an 8/32 = <<8/32=0.25>>0.25 or 25% chance of picking a green M&M. Answer: \boxed{25}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

The boy gives 12/3 = <<12/3=4>>4 oranges to his brother.
The remainder is 12 - 4 = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges.
The boy gives his friend 8/4 = <<8/4=2>>2 oranges. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

One-third of 12 is (1/3)*12 = <<(1/3)*12=4>>4 oranges.
The remainder is 12-4 = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges.
One-fourth of 8 is (1/4)*8 = <<(1/4)*8=2>>2 oranges. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A boy has 12 oranges. He gives one-third of this number to his brother, one-fourth of the remainder to his friend and keeps the rest for himself. How many does his friend get?

One-third of 12 oranges is (1/3)*12 = <<(1/3)*12=4>>4 oranges.
The first boy remains with 12 oranges - 4 oranges = <<12-4=8>>8 oranges after giving out some to his brother.
One-fourth of 8 oranges is (1/4)*8 = <<(1/4)*8=2>>2 oranges. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A jar contains 9 blue pens, 21 black pens, and 6 red pens. Four blue pens are removed and then seven black pens are removed. How many pens are left in the jar?
text:
Before any pens are removed, there are 9 + 21 + 6 = <<9+21+6=36>>36 pens in total.
After removing four blue pens, there are 36 - 4 = <<36-4=32>>32 pens remaining.
After removing seven black pens, there are 32 - 7 = <<32-7=25>>25 pens left in the jar. Answer: \boxed{25}.

Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby has 5 balls * 80 rotations per ball = <<5*80=400>>400 rotations.
Toby's friend has 4 apples * 101 rotations per apple = <<4*101=404>>404 rotations.
The winner has 404 >=  400 meaning the maximum is 404 rotations. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby rotates 400 baseballs because 5 x 80 = <<5*80=400>>400
His friend rotates 404 apples because 4 x 101 = <<4*101=404>>404
His friend wins because 404 > 400.
The winner rotates 404 objects. Answer: \boxed{404}.

Toby makes 400 rotations because 5 x 80 = <<5*80=400>>400
His friend does 404 rotations because 4 x 101 = <<4*101=404>>404
The winner made 404 rotations because 404 > 400
The winner made 404 rotations because 404 > 400. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: Toby is in a juggling contest with a friend. The winner is whoever gets the most objects rotated around in 4 minutes. Toby has 5 baseballs and each one makes 80 rotations. His friend has 4 apples and each one makes 101 rotations. How many total rotations of objects are made by the winner?

Toby's baseballs make a total of 5 x 80 = <<5*80=400>>400 rotations.
His friend's apples make 4 x 101 = <<4*101=404>>404 rotations.
The total rotations made by the winner are 404 rotations. Answer: \boxed{404}.


Question: Grayson has 100 questions on a test. He answers some of the questions for 2 hours, taking two minutes for each answer, then realizes he doesn't know the rest of the questions. How many questions does Grayson leave unanswered when he submits his test?

Two hours is 2*60 = <<2*60=120>>120 minutes
He takes 120 / 2 = <<120/2=60>>60 questions answered
He has to answer 100 - 60 = <<100-60=40>>40 questions. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: Billy has 8 hours of free time on each day of the weekend. He wants to spend 75% of his time playing video games and the rest of his time reading. He can read 60 pages an hour and his books all contain 80 pages. How many books does he read?
text:
Billy has 8 hours x 2 = <<8*2=16>>16 hours of free time on the weekend.
He spends 75% of his time playing video games, which is 16 x 0.75 = <<16*0.75=12>>12 hours.
He spends 16 - 12 = <<16-12=4>>4 hours reading.
He can read 4 hours x 60 pages per hour = <<4*60=240>>240 pages.
He can read 240 pages / 80 pages per book = <<240/80=3>>3 books.
Billy reads 3 books. Answer: \boxed{3}.
